title: 109_hr1237
content: The "Brownfield Redevelopment Assistance Act of 2005" aims to provide targeted assistance for projects that promote the redevelopment of brownfield sites and eco-industrial development. It also aims to restore employment and tax bases in distressed communities lacking private sector support for essential public services. The Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 is amended to include definitions for "brownfield site" and "eco-industrial development." The Act aims to provide funding for site characterization, assessment, and remediation of brownfield sites. The Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 is amended to include definitions for "brownfield site" and "eco-industrial development." Eco-industrial development involves businesses cooperating to efficiently share resources for economic gains, improved environmental quality, and equitable enhancement of human resources. Additionally, the definition of "unused land" is added to include publicly or privately owned land that is not contributing to the community's well-being. SEC. 4 amends the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 to coordinate brownfield site redevelopment activities with various entities. SEC. 5 introduces grants for brownfield site redevelopment under the Act. The Secretary may make grants for projects to alleviate conditions associated with brownfield sites, including development of public facilities, services, business, planning, technical assistance, training, and purchase of environmental insurance. Grants are provided if the project will assist in redevelopment activities. The Secretary may provide grants for projects addressing special needs in areas with high unemployment, blight, dislocations from restructuring, and outmigration leading to population loss and capital depletion. The Secretary may provide grants for projects addressing special needs in areas with high unemployment, blight, dislocations from restructuring, and outmigration leading to population loss and capital depletion. The grants may be used for projects related to fiscal pressure, restricted access to markets, constrained local development potential, and the closure or realignment of military or Federal facilities. The Secretary provides grants for projects in areas with economic challenges, requiring approval of a comprehensive economic development strategy. Assistance may include revitalizing affected areas through diversification or redevelopment projects on brownfield sites, and conserving land through development projects. The grants aim to revitalize areas with economic challenges by conserving land through development that reuses existing facilities, promotes eco-industrial development, and involves community participation in economic planning. Eligible recipients can directly expend the funds for approved projects. Eligible recipients of grants can use the funds for approved projects or redistribute them to public and private entities in various forms of assistance. Private for-profit entities are not eligible to receive grants. Sec. 219 authorizes grants for Brownfield site redevelopment. Section 611 and its related item in the table of contents are repealed. Authorization of appropriations for Brownfield site redevelopment is provided in SEC. 6 of the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965. Eligible recipients can use the funds for approved projects or provide assistance to public and private entities. Authorization of $60,000,000 for Brownfield site redevelopment annually from 2006 to 2010, with a Federal share of up to 75%. Conforming amendment to the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965.
